segments.text: Your full name, please, sir, and a little about your personal background, your early years, and how you came to be associated with Mitchell Energy.
Okay, it's Bernard F. Clark, although I've gone by the nickname Bud, with two Ds, for some reason, ever since high school.
I was born and grew up in New York City, and went to
Fordham Preparatory School, because I had a scholarship for it, and then to Fordham University, where I studied chemistry, and so I was able to get a loan and a grant and work at the school.
I joined the ROTC at the time, this is 1938 to 1942, mainly to get the
monthly check in the junior year bonanza to help pay for the schooling.
Like some people in the Persian Gulf are finding out now, if you take the money, you go.
In my case, it paid.
So since I had chemistry, I was switched into the chemical warfare service from Coast Artillery, which was the ROTC group at Edgewater.
And then when I got down to Aberdeen, which is the Army chemical depot, they needed three or four people in the Air Corps.
So fortunately, I got switched to that, which I then headed south at MacDill Field and spent an amazing majority of my time at Hartsdale.
And the last part at Edmund Field was testing weapons, chemical weapons.
You were at Barksdale during the war?
From 52 to 42 to 44.
Is that right?
Yeah.
The strange thing is, Ken Patterson, who was in charge of the gas sales, was the commanding officer of Barksdale.
And he retired now working for us.
But you said some odd grouping gets into place.
Yeah, it really does.
So anyhow, I went back up to New York to get a job and called on
GE, Selenese, and Pan American Petroleum and Transport, which is now called Amacom, or Wesley, one part of Amacom.
So at 42nd Street, I got a job in Texas City, Texas.
That's where the lab was.
And I came down and saw that there was no way I could get anywhere without a PhD.
Things had changed too much during the war.
So I heard about the Harvard Business School from my wife and applied and was accepted.
And then we went up there from 47 to 49.
You missed the big explosion down in Texas City?
No.
You were there?
We were there.
My wife was working at Carbide, and I was at Pan Am.
And the explosion was down at the Harvard, which was about three miles away.
Shocking glass where she was.
She was over at the next plant down.
But at the refinery.
Well, the main thing there was a good big, I guess, 40-foot section of pipe that looked like a javelin throwhead.
So I had to stick it in there.
And that one missed the main crew line by, say, six feet.
I don't know.
People were exaggerating at the time like that.
So that was in 1947.
And we went to Harvard in September.
Were you sort of thinking career change or direction?
Well, actually, I wrote this up.
And I wrote to some of the men and had articles about them and asked them whether a combination of a business degree with a technical degree was a good idea.
And they looked like, yes.
So it was more of that.
Because that was rather rare at that time, wasn't it?
Well, also, I saw petrochemicals being a hell of a big deal.
I read everything I could on there.
So when I came out of Harvard, actually, I increased my salary $15 a month by getting an MBA.
I went to J.T.
Baker Chemical Company, which is in the city area of Dick Chemical, because I wanted to get the chemical side.
I had the petroleum side of New Orleans.
Then I watched from New Orleans.
So when Amoco started up with Standard of Indiana, of course, started up another sub down in New Orleans, we came down here.
And then when they decided to do away with it five years later, I sent a
resume to Boston to the school, and one over here to Houston to one of the alumni.
And as a result, I got Conoco to come over, and George's partner, Marilyn Christian, had to come over.
And I had a meeting with him, which was not the, what one might say, the normal interview.
The gist of it was that, I'm telling my wife, I was a bit crazy.
She said, well, you'll fit.
Actually, it was the first.
What year was this?
I'll flip that over any time you want me to.
Well, flip it over.
OK, wait a moment.
I said, OK, so we came here.
What year was that again?
Yeah, so I went from general manager
to vice president, to executive vice president, to vice chairman, and I guess to ex-vice chairman at some point.
Now, when you came in 56, could you sort of describe the status of Mitchell, Henry, or CMM, and what was going on, where you were doing your primary work?
I would say there might be something.
The controversy with George, he is my version of it, because his version is always different.
But there's about 225 employees, 225 to 250.
And there was no order, no organization.
Even to this day, there is a certain, if you look at the table of organization, or create one,
I had some consultants sit over 12 years ago.
And I said, George, here's your table organization.
And they drew five circles and put George in the middle.
And I said, everybody reports you.
So it was pretty much that way, except the circles got twisted up.
So I imagine that was one of the purposes of me over here as a non-accountant.
And I don't need a chemist, although I would understand technical matters.
It was more or less administration.
George at that time was handling the finance, because mainly it was natural gas pipeline was advancing money to keep you on the well.
And he did banking with Dr. Vance, who was over in Bank Southwest.
And the, but as time went on, I took over the bank in about 59.
So you already came into the business sector.
You really weren't doing much in terms of... Oh, no.
There's been one thing, any time I get an operations course and they're like, so one time he'll tell me, you know, stay out.
He'll say, have an operations course.
And I can roam the rest of it.
Cross over, get in the foot.
I appreciate it.
So that's pretty much the way it's been.
Up until 76 and then...
We set up a refinancing and turned it over to Tony and turned it over to Smith.
And it's pretty much on a routine.
Well, they won't say it.
They won't appreciate it.
I thought it was .
So it's not routine.
Smith keeps coming up with new games.
But compared to the way we had to beg, borrow, and steal money in the old days, it's routine.
It's a different world.
Most of the activity
Yeah.
Wise County, Palacios, Vienna.
Now, when did real estate begin to iterate into the picture?
Well, on the side, Johnny Mitchell had made friends with Norman Dobbins, who actually and his wife were interior decorators, and Norman had a flair for design, so he talked
He had started the home building company.
Johnny was coming into it.
So Merlin and George, they took half, and Norman had half.
So we were sort of in the home building business.
And a leftover of that is Imperial Valley, or the Esplanade, was the commercial that was left after the subdivision was built there.
So that's really, you might say, the start.
Then about, I think, 62, and this you'd have to check with George,
bought the land down at Pirates Beach.
And that was really the first development time?
Yeah.
The real development?
Yeah.
What precipitated that?
Because in 1962, Galveston was not exactly what you call a booming.
George saw the golden city on the hill and had been building that golden city .
That's why.
The way it was in the 1890s.
That's an old story.
It's still there.
It's still part of the 80s.
Part.
It's it.
How do you build a building like that in San Luis?
Book of Return coming out.
Obviously I had to do it.
the real estate business, let's say, was in any way competitive with the oil business, or that it was diverting energies or anything?
Not at that time.
Then he bought the Grogan Dockers, which I believe was 1964.
And the two of us went around financing it, which we had no luck.
But he financed it with an outfit here in town, which just proved at much better rates and terms
He just proved what his damn persistence was good for.
Yeah.
And the next thing was he bought Pelican Island.
His brother knew that the DeVoe Company, I think it was DeVoe, owned it and had a big tax gain.
The Georgians said, look, they put that $7 million in there, but they had that bridge.
And he said, well, look, why don't you take, now's the time to take your tax loss again.
So he talked them into it.
So now Pelican sort of came out.
The woodlands have come out.
I mean, the timberlands have come out.
They've been paid $125, of which only $40 was land.
The rest was timber.
And they have paid for themselves over and over, sort of like goddamn Toll Bridge.
And Pelican paid for itself.
But they're loaded with debt that came from elsewhere.
The overhead at Woodlands was beginning.
The losses, et cetera.
It all got dumped over here, and now you can't find it, trace it.
Now, once, at the point where I saw he could get it to be, it was really 1967, was the first evening I had that he was out to build the city.
Now, I'll tell you one thing about the Timberlands, the 50,000 acres.
He put those together all by himself, an attorney from Vincent Elkins, and a forester who was working on the road.
Got it.
The company was not involved in any which way.
It was all 273 damn transactions he talks about.
I'm scared.
Yeah.
So once that started, I said, OK. And then I had to go around to other places.
Well, I'd just seen Zach and Dolphin got broke.
And George says, well, you don't lose money and land just on developing it.
Yes.
Who developed it?
So it was a constant.
Now, Woodland, the only positive or even negative thing I had to deal with was the 50,000 bonds.
I personally handled the sale of dealing with underwriters by public debt and doing it by phone.
I did that, but once you get past that.
Oh, now, back on the recreational,
I worked up with the marketing people, and I had to see if you could get it going better.
In the women's marketing?
No, no, no, no.
It had to be Galveston, and Livingston, and up here.
I brought in some people from California, and worked with them.
Those are my two connections with it.
Interview over.
Interview over.
Well, let's talk about it.
